lines.text: What goes on here?
Life, my boy. And death, of course. You can't have one without the other.
My name is Bilby and I'm looking for the parasol department. The clerk said, "First left and straight on 'til morning," but that can't be right!
They're nice people, aren't they? A little odd, I'll grant you that, but after forty years in this place, I expect I'll be a little odd myself.
Tell me, Harkins, are you happy here?
No, madam, I'm not happy here.
But you stay on?
Yes, madam, I stay on.
Why do you?
I'm so frightened of the dark men!
Nobody knows we live here, and nobody must ever know. Once we're discovered, it's the end of us.

I've lived here since the crash of '97. I've survived two mergers, three complete redecorations and the move from 14th Street. It required many sacrifices. May I say, I hope you're not the latest of them.
They don't feed me. When they're through, I get what's left. They're skinny but they eat like elephants. I saw an elephant once when I was little and I know what elephants can eat!
Harkins, who are these dark men?
There's a famous mortuary in Manhattan. Journey's End, I think it's called.
Yeah, I've heard of it.
Well, people live there, just like here.
Live in a mortuary? Well, how can they? What... What do they live on?
Were you born here?
No, I came when I was six.
That's amazing. You renounced the world when you were six!
You haven't seen the sun for 13 years?
Oh, don't pity me. I have my memories.
I can't read or write, I don't know what the world is...
What? You can't read or write?
I never finished kindergarten.
Oh, that's wonderful! I'll teach you, like Pygmalion!
I don't know anything. I've never spoken to a man before who wasn't old. I've never touched a face that wasn't wrinkled.
We don't dare see each other again, it's too dangerous. They're watching us!
I don't see anybody.
You never can. They watch in secret ways!
We're an exclusive group. For years, I was the only member!
Mrs. Monday will be told. You will be sent for. There will be punishment.

I'm reminded of the tragic story of young Phipps. Long years ago, there was a velvet smoking jacket on display. Young Phipps conceived a passion for it. Naturally the thing got sold and Phipps, his reason gone, emerged and tore it from a customer. We lived for months in terror dreading an investigation. What happened to the smoking jacket, no one knows. As for young Phipps, we had to call the dark men.
An intruder!
Call the dark men!
Yes, call the dark men!
Call the dark men!
That's for Mrs. Monday to decide.
Charles, she's not one of us.
Well, why not? She lives here, doesn't she?
We keep her in the bargain basement, Seconds and Rejects department.
You keep her? Is the girl a prisoner?
